YEAR BOOK EDITOR
RESIGNS POSITION
Paul Cordish Graduates and
Enters Yale Law School
SITUATION

UNUSUAL

Successor To Be Chosen By
Senior Class
Paul Cordish, Editor-in-Chief
elect of the 1930 Hullabaloo, has
resigned his office in view of the
fact that he was able to graduate
in June and is now studying law at
Yale University. Cordish was elected to this position at the Junior
Class Banquet last April.
Letter

Cordish officially resigned in a
letter to Purnell Hall, president of
the Student Council, which follows:
Wm. Purnell Hall,
President of Student Council, •
Johns Hopkins University.
Dear Mr. Hall:
As you know, I was elected to
edit the 1930 Hullabaloo. Several
weeks after the election last April,
events occurred making it necessary
for me to graduate ahead of my
class. Owing to the uncertainty of
my graduation, and the examination turmoil, it would have been
foolish to have then resigned.
Some work had to be done during the summer, and after securing
permission from Dr. Ames to act,
I, with the Business Manager, let
the engraving contract. In spite of
the fact that I still occupied the
editorial chair, I did not deem it
wise to let the printing contract, as
it could wait in the first place and
as I had no desire to bind my successor in any way.
Having graduated, and being registered here at Yale, I must resign
this position of trust with which
I have been honored by my class.
Before leaving, Mr. Gump, Mr.
Gettemuller, and I met and a tentative plan for selection was evolved.
These gentlemen are well able to
manage the selection of an editor
who will be worthy, and-who, I hope
will turn out the finest yearbook
Hopkins has ever had.
All work done to date has had
the full concurrence of the Business Manager, Mr. Gettemuller.
Wishing my class, Johns Hopkins, 1930, all the successes and
triumphs that it so well deserves
for its past and present
services
to the University, I
am,
Respectfully,
PAUL L. CORDISH.
Unprecedented Situation

The resignation of Cordish leaves
an unprecedented situation. George
Gump, the managing editor, cannot
be elected Editor-in-Chief, due to
the ruling of the Student Activities
Council, which prevents a man from
holding more than one major office.
(i.e., Editor-in-Chief or Business
Manager) in a student publication.
Therefore it will be necessary for
the Senior Class to elect a new editor.
At today's meeting of the Class
cf 1930 it is probable that this election will be discussed as well as the
election of the class president and
the senior Student Council
representatives. This meeting is to be held
in Room 120, C. E. Hall,
at 12.30.
In the meantime George Gettemuller, Business Manager, and
George Gump, Managing Editor,
are handling the affairs of the 1930
annual. As there is little work done
cn the Hullabaloo at this time of
the year,the resignation of the editor will not cause any immediate
difficulties.

We wore black ties; we entered Gilman Hall through the tunnel
only, splashing ourselves with mud on the way necessarily; we were
paddled for keeping our hands in our pockets; we were paddled for
walking on the grass; we were paddled for not knowing "Who's
Who"; we were paddled for knowing "Who's Who." Yet many
of the upperclassmen thought something was wrong with the system
and their views were listened to with increasing respect. It was at
the time when a wave of feeling against frosh rules was spreading
throughout the country.
Then came the historic Annihilation of Annapolis. The story of
that struggle has been told and retold so often that it is needless to
dwell upon it further. That event probably did more to ameliorate
the harshness of freshman regulations and the consequent fights than
any other single event. For when the Class of '30 became sophomores
they checked paddling and the first step toward the abolition of freshman regulations was accomplished.
But the new system worked very, very badly. The regulations were
supposed to be obeyed, but there was nobody to enforce them. Theoretically the plan was perfect, practically it proved to be a dismal
failure. The road was clear; either the old paddles would have to be
renovated or the regulations abolished in toto. This year witnesses
the solution; and the correct one, we feel sure.
Before praising .the new system, we must first see what the old
intended to accomplish. In the first place, freshman regulations were
intended to teach the yearlings their proper place, and it did so undoubtedly. Yet anyone who takes the trouble to review his own freshman days (or daze) can realize that no regulations were necessary to
keep him in his place. The average freshman can see exactly how
unimportant he is. The faculty with its eternal "No admittance to
this course," and "Keep out of here," furnishes a far better example
than even the most hardened member of a sophomore pep-committee.
And if freshmen are still unconvinced by their instructors, fraternities
certainly leave no doubt in their minds. Of course, rushing season has
the opposite effect, but once the little button is securely fastened, the
.attitude changes. We know of no better cure for a superiority complex
than a bucket of soapy water, a rag, and a nice, dirty floor.

Many friends were made by that ruling and we view its departure
with the feeling that an old and worthy tradition has passed away.

NEWS-LETTER,
Dear Sir:
Every year, six hundred and
seven students, and other persons
taking courses at the Johns Hopkins University, write various letters from time to time to the NEWSLETTER lamenting the lack of freshmen regulations. What with the
complete absence of the aforementioned this year, undoubtedly the
upperclassmen will still bring up
the subject.
The "Y" Handbook gives an interesting page or two to the describing of what will be required this
year of the freshmen, and composing the largest class since the University was threatened with the New
Plan. Freshmen are advised that
they should carry out these extremely few regulations to the n'th degree
or face the consequences. These are
to be found at the top of page thirtyfive.
All joking (?) aside we wish to
personally advise the new men that
"Attendance at the weekly assemblies * * * is the only duty imposed"
is also the bunk. "We know students who never attended any assembly and they never were susFended, etc., etc." One should attend one or two of them just for
fun, however.
This policy probably is the answer
to the complaints of those "letterwriters" of last year who insistently

demanded that the regulations be
completely enforced or dropped altogether. Since the latter has happened; and this article has been
written forstalling such, not more
than six hundred and six letters
will be written this year.
On one hand we have the plaudits
of those who are glad to see tlic.
last remnants of childishness vanish
from the campus and on the other
hand we have the howls of anguish
of those who hate to see the passing of the last traditions of the good
old days when there was really such
a thing known as college spirit.
Perhaps the first group contains
the majority. Or perhaps the second group will rise en masse and
cause a large number of pencilled
notations to be added on that practically blank page of the "Y" Handbook. Quien Sabet
Sincerely,

To the Editor of the
NEWS-LETTER,

attention that a number of the departments change the books required for each course from one
year to another. Notable instances
of these are the French and English
departments. I do not see any
cause or purpose in this practice
and as it offers a serious financial,
as well as scholarly, (as it makes
impossible any pre-summer study)
handicap. I would suggest that it
be discontinued.
Sincerely,

YEAR BOOK EDITOR
RESIGNS POSITION
Paul Cordish Graduates and
Enters Yale Law School
SITUATION

UNUSUAL

Successor To Be Chosen By
Senior Class
Paul Cordish, Editor-in-Chief
elect of the 1930 Hullabaloo, has
resigned his office in view of the
fact that he was able to graduate
in June and is now studying law at
Yale University. Cordish was elected to this position at the Junior
Class Banquet last April.
Letter

Cordish officially resigned in a
letter to Purnell Hall, president of
the Student Council, which follows:
Wm. Purnell Hall,
President of Student Council, •
Johns Hopkins University.
Dear Mr. Hall:
As you know, I was elected to
edit the 1930 Hullabaloo. Several
weeks after the election last April,
events occurred making it necessary
for me to graduate ahead of my
class. Owing to the uncertainty of
my graduation, and the examination turmoil, it would have been
foolish to have then resigned.
Some work had to be done during the summer, and after securing
permission from Dr. Ames to act,
I, with the Business Manager, let
the engraving contract. In spite of
the fact that I still occupied the
editorial chair, I did not deem it
wise to let the printing contract, as
it could wait in the first place and
as I had no desire to bind my successor in any way.
Having graduated, and being registered here at Yale, I must resign
this position of trust with which
I have been honored by my class.
Before leaving, Mr. Gump, Mr.
Gettemuller, and I met and a tentative plan for selection was evolved.
These gentlemen are well able to
manage the selection of an editor
who will be worthy, and-who, I hope
will turn out the finest yearbook
Hopkins has ever had.
All work done to date has had
the full concurrence of the Business Manager, Mr. Gettemuller.
Wishing my class, Johns Hopkins, 1930, all the successes and
triumphs that it so well deserves
for its past and present
services
to the University, I
am,
Respectfully,
PAUL L. CORDISH.
Unprecedented Situation

The resignation of Cordish leaves
an unprecedented situation. George
Gump, the managing editor, cannot
be elected Editor-in-Chief, due to
the ruling of the Student Activities
Council, which prevents a man from
holding more than one major office.
(i.e., Editor-in-Chief or Business
Manager) in a student publication.
Therefore it will be necessary for
the Senior Class to elect a new editor.
At today's meeting of the Class
cf 1930 it is probable that this election will be discussed as well as the
election of the class president and
the senior Student Council
representatives. This meeting is to be held
in Room 120, C. E. Hall,
at 12.30.
In the meantime George Gettemuller, Business Manager, and
George Gump, Managing Editor,
are handling the affairs of the 1930
annual. As there is little work done
cn the Hullabaloo at this time of
the year,the resignation of the editor will not cause any immediate
difficulties.

Interfraternity Board
Holds First Meeting
Last Wednesday, at 12.30, the
first Interfraiernity Board meeting
was held. As no notices were placed
in post office boxes, due to the fact
that all the boxes had not been assigned and marked, there were no
fines imposed for absences. However, representatives from all but
three of the Greek-letter societies
on the Board were present.
It was decided to hold the future
meetings in the M. E. Building as
in the past. The next meeting will
probably take place Mcinday. If
any change in the representatives is
to be made, written notice should
be given John Yellott at once, as
a ruling was passed last year requiring that the Board vote on any
new delegates sent except at the
regular time.

DATES OF CLASS
MEETINGS CHANGED
The dates for the meetings
of the three upper classes have
been changed. The sophomores will meet Monday, the
juniors Tuesday, and the seniors Thursday. All these meetings will be held in the C. E.
Hall at 12.30 on the respective
dates. Class officers and Student Council representatives
will be nominated at this time
and elected at a later date. The
senior class will also take up
the matter of electing the Hallabaloo editor. The latter election is due to the resignation
of Paul Cordish.

PRESENT CLASS OF FRESHMEN PROVE
NO WISER THAN THEIR PREDECESSORS
Despite the fact that freshman
regulations are obsolete and subsequently the newcomers appear more
dignified than they ordinarily would,
several incidents have occurred to
show that the present crop is just
as green as any former entering
class. Last year, it might be remembered, the unsuspecting freshmen
were put to the rather unpleasant
job of dipping fingers in ink and
then pressing down the prints. The
result made rather good copy for
the first issue of the Black and Blue
Jay.
Another incident proved conclusively that the frosh were pretty
dumb. One freshman was told to
find out the name of Don Hess's
brother. Realizing that the dictionary is a good source, the yearling
vainly thumbed the pages of Webster in order to gain his information. Failing to do so, he next
sought his end in a chemistry dictionary.
This year's crop of new men are
of no higher order as events have
proved. Several days ago one freshman was seen to wander anxiously
from one building to another on the
campus. Finally when questioned
he doefully admitted that he had
found Remsen Hall, Levering Hall,
Gilman Hall, C. E. Hall, and M. E.

Hall, but that he could not locate
Purnell Hall.
And then there is the story of the
freshman who approached the goal
tender of last year's lacrosse team,
put a friendly arm around the lacrosse player's shoulder and cheerfully said, "Say, bud, got a light?"
But the height of freshness and
unsophistication was reached when
one freshman deposited a nickel in
the pile Of NEWS-LETTERS in the
post office of Gilman Hall in exchange for one of the copies. Not
realizing that his NEWS-LETTER was
covered by his activities fee, the
unknowing frosh had taken literally
this caption, on the front of the
college newspaper: Price 5 cents.
Who said freshmen aren't dumb?
